question:
Does the chest X-ray show signs of pleural effusion? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_1:
Does the chest X-ray demonstrate the presence of pleural effusion, characterized by increased opacity in the costophrenic angle? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]

variation_2:
Does the chest X-ray show signs of pleural effusion? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]

variation_3:
Is there visual evidence on the chest X-ray of fluid accumulation between the lung and chest wall, consistent with a diagnosis of pleural effusion? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_4:
Are signs suggestive of pleural effusion visible on the chest X-ray, including blunting of the costophrenic angle and increased density in the lower thorax? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]

variation_5:
Does the chest radiograph show evidence of fluid-filled space between the lung and chest wall, diagnostic of pleural effusion? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]

variation_6:
Is there visual indication on the chest X-ray of increased fluid in the pleural space, leading to opacity and blunting of the costophrenic angle? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_7:
Are pleural effusion signs detectable on the chest radiograph, including increased density and blurring of the lung-chest wall interface? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_8:
Does the chest X-ray display features suggestive of fluid accumulation in the pleural space, such as meniscus sign or Kerley B lines? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
<image>
variation_9:
Is visual evidence present on the chest X-ray of increased interstitial fluid, leading to a diagnosis of pleural effusion and/or pulmonary edema? Please choose from the following two options: [yes, no]
